text: I grew up in Germany and moved to San Diego six years ago. This is the first legit German bakery I have found so far. Visited this morning and tried the bee sting cake, cinnamon roll, cheese danish and jelly donut. JUST LIKE BACK HOME!! I even teared up a little. You have to understand I have always been a huge fan of our pastries back home and have been looking ever since I immigrated. Got to chat with the very friendly owner in German too. Go there, you won't be disappointed!

Happened to stumble upon this place by accident and decided to go in.  It appears to be a traditional German bakery.  The girl behid the counter was very nice and conviced me to purchase a cake.  I decided to try the Black Forest Cake, which is a chocolate cake with layers of cream.  When I went to pay for it, I noticed they were going to put it in a bag.  I asked for a box because I wanted to place it in an ice chest to transport it home (it was 100 degrees outside) and I did not want it getting smashed or ruined.  A guy there, who appeared to be the owner, said no he will not put one item in a box because it costs too much.  I understand if I had bought some bread or items that are not "delicate", but this was a layer cake.  I never heard of putting a piece of cake in a paper bag.  Needless to say, I said "No thank you" and left the store without purchasing anything and I will not be back.  I also decided not to purchase other items that I was looking at.  It is sad that the owner lost a potential customer over properly prackaging a piece of cake so that it can be transported without falling apart or making a mess.   Too bad the women that was behind the counter is not the owner becasue she appeared to be a lot more customer oriented and a good sales person.

I am a regular here, since the day they opened. Love their breads and pastries, everything fresh, crunchy and yummie. I freeze the breads and rolls and enjoy the constant supply of good, fresh baked items for me and my family. Five stars also for the meats and other German products they sell and the service, always friendly.

If this is what bread is like in Germany, I want to live there. Sigh. Don't be fooled by the name, the shop also sells yummy pastries and pretzels. I tried the raisin snail and was blown away by the deliciously light pastry. From the outside it looked like it was going to be a sugar bomb, but actually ended up being not too sweet. A generous portion of raisins plus the lightest skimming of sweet glaze made this treat perfect. The girls behind the counter were also really friendly and nice, I would have enjoyed stopping by just to chat with them. I actually wish this place wasn't so close to my house... I can see it becoming an addiction, FAST.

I used to live in Munich and this bakery reminds me of places in Germany!

The moment you step in you realize how organized and sterile they are,
bread tastes wonderful!!
Couple of my American Friends go their all the time after I let them try how healthy bread tastes.

I don't need to add to the reviews here, as they've got this place covered better than I could. What I do want to add is that everything I've tried here is simply the best I've eaten in a very long time. The flavors are just... right. Delicious. Incredible.

Honestly have nothing to complain about. I wish more places were like this.

Nice place clean and wonderful baked goods no doubt grandmas recipes however is taking a turn for the worst the slicer is so thin of a cut I defiantly don't recommend any sliced bread but the quality is awesome

We had 4 things today. Cherry Danish, had great pastry but a little lacking on the cherry filling, which is of course what we wanted. Rebounded with Cherry crumb cake
. We got our cherries and then some. Have 2 pretzels for happy hour and made Obatzda for dipping. Should be good. Also got strudels fro my son in law, looked good but did not get to try

Excellent German Breads made in house.
Pastries are hit and miss. Prices are very reasonable so you can buy a few and see what you like. Their Lemon Rolls are a Hit; the Pretzel breads are doughy and lack crunch. 
This Bakery has great potential - several sweet items also have a doughy texture problem that needs to be fixed.

I've popped my head in once or twice when we were in the area and we were defiantly impressed. 

I bought some pretzel rolls (The best of the pretzels they have) and accidentally ate them all when I got home. I bought some yeast bread for the household and came home later and it was already gone. 

The prices are great, and I hope they open a location in Centennial Hills!

On Rampart one day I saw a "sign dancer" with a sign for a German Bakery.  I asked a coworker if she knew of the place and she had great things to say about German baked goods.  I have been looking for a high quality rye bread for tea sandwiches I am making and this place has just that.  A few choices of rye actually.  I picked up some pretzels, a chocolate croissant, a loaf of marbel rye and a loaf of sourdough.  The pretzel has great flavor & texture and I can't wait to try the other stuff.

The staff (2 ladies) were really nice and helpful.   I was worried about slicing the bread into even slices but no worries here - they have a bread slicer and were happy to do it for me.  

The only thing I was sad about was that the "sign dancer"  came into the store for a few minutes before returning to the 112 degree heat.  I hope his shift isn't 8 hours.

I'm so glad that there's a German Bakery here in Vegas! I finally visited yesterday and it brought back memories of being a military brat in Germany. I definatly had to buy all 3 types of Pretzel (Roll, stick, and twist), two Knorr mix packets, and a Beesting cake. My mother bought the Brochen and one of those big pig's ear pastries. Everything tastes great! I can't wait to visit again to try out other breads and pastries.

Lived in Germany many years and it was so fun to come across this bit of heaven. Gobbled up tons of comfort items to take home and create a German feast.  I loved the authenticity of the ladies speaking German to each other.   Definitely will be back again and again for a bit of comfort and home.  Danke Fr√§ulein!
Mmmm, I drool just thinking about this place.  What here isn't good is the question, only bad part is when I don't make it in time and they sellout of all the good stuff
First of all, I have to say the almond horns are amazing!  Everything lives up to it's name and the staff couldn't be more helpful.
One of the best bakeries in Vegas. Their pastries are fresh, interesting, and delicious! They don't taste artificial or heavy in icing. Just very light and delicious flavor.

Quaint European bakery with an old world feel.  We ordered a variety of pastries, lemon roll, almond twist, cherry strudel, chocolate croissant, cheese Danish, rum ball and chocolate coin - all were fresh and so good I'm sure they were baked with love.  Disappointed there was no seating to enjoy our coffee and goodies although it seemed there was adequate space to accommodate some small tables and a few chairs.  Also, the stiff coffee will put hair on your chest.  I give the German Bakery 5-stars in spite of the coffee and lack of seating because our pastries were perfect.
I just tried some of their holiday Stollen for breakfast this morning and it was delicious!  So happy to have a local place that knows how to make one of my favorite Christmas treats.

Growing up my whole life in Germany I highly recommend this bakery! I hasn't been able to find any bakery in America that had the exact delicious authentic German pastries I had while growing up, until I found this place! I assume it's be owned by a real German because the recipes taste and look so authentic and identical to any bakery in Germany! I haven't bought one thing here I didn't like! The price is worth the high quality! Very very pleased with this business, esp this location-had a slightly larger variety compared to the other location and the staff was also very/more friendly!!

So bomb,like everyone else said. Good balance for my taste buds, really nice employees. 
I will never get those overpriced garbage tasting pastries at starbucks n other coffee shops ever again!!!
The pretzels roll and pudding danish is so on point.

We are new to Las Vegas, just moved into South Shores two weeks ago. I saw the German Bread Bakery and thought I'd stop in. And that was the last time I'll stop in. The woman who waited on me was most unfriendly, like she was doing me a favor selling me a loaf of bread. Now if you were in a niche business, selling bread at over $5.00 a loaf, you think you'd be nice to your customers. Not. I'll buy my bread at Smith's and skip the attitude.

This place is a DREAM COME TRUE for anyone from the Northeast....They have the most AMAZING hard rolls.... yup, crispy on the outside and soft on the inside!!

We have also been enjoying there pretzels (rolls, sticks) they are great to eat alone, but we love them as hamburger bun and hotdog bun :)

Can't say enough about this place, GREAT people making GREAT bread!

There are not many things I miss about growing up and spending 21 years in Germany, but the bread and pastries are definitely on top of that list. Thanks to the folks at the German Bread Bakery for filling the void, the German rolls are identical to the ones I grew up with, so is the rye bread! Every single time a trip down memory lane...

I don't understand how this place has almost 5 stars! Came in this morning and honestly left disappointed and baffle by all the reviews 
Pastries were not fresh, there is not an oven or microwave to warm your pastries nowhere to sit down all the shelves were almost empty.
I definitely won't be coming back this bakery does not represent in any way a German bakery 
I ordered a pretzel cold croissant and my husband ordered a bear claw but because it was not enough to pay with a credit card we had to purchase another pastry a "pig ear" which was as Cold and hard as the other two pastries...;(
Yummy stuff! NW of the strip, a drive but worth it. Not a huge selection, but maybe we were too late in the day. I will try it again when I visit the next time.
Wonderful pastries. I especially love their pretzel rolls, just don't make the mistake of asking if they sell nacho cheese...this is a German bakery, you can have mustard.

Pretty close as you can get to German baked goods compared to our experience while living in Germany. They also have a variety of german packaged foods. I'm so glad they sell fennel tea here which I miss back in Germany. It's great in relieving tummy aches for my kids. However I wish they had HIPP brand products as well- my favorite and go to brand while we lived there. Anyways, we'll definitely be regular customers at this place.

I have been here several times. Always on Saturday mornings. I love it except that every time I get the Brochen, I am disappointed and had to throw them all away last week because they were very stale to point of not being able to cut them without crumbling. I realize that they are stored in the open air but even so, a few hours shouldn't make that much of a difference. Is it possible that Saturday's the items aren't baked fresh but leftover from the day before???? I'll have to take a vacation day to try during the week. :) 

Everything else is fantastic especially the Dark Rye Bread and deli meat but I really want good Brochen!

Mmmm yes! This place took me back to when i was in germany and staying with my host family! God i forgot how good german baked goods are! The prezel bread is so good and the apple pie was phenomenal!!! Highly recommend this place!

They added meats & German groceries, and we've been thrilled with the quality of the products.  Add that to the low prices and the incredible baked goods, the only thing that would improve things would be if they moved closer to my house =D

We have been shopping at Smiths in this plaza for years and have always wanted to try this Bakery. When my family from Hawaii flew up here they told us that this bakery gets a lot of 5 stars on Yelp. They had bought pastries for us to try and they were delicious. We  tried new ones today. We were greeted warmly by Jean, she was very friendly and helpful. We ended up trying the apple & cherry strudel, rum ball, Berliner and pizza pastry and a vanilla cake it was all very good. My only problem is with the Berliner, the sugar coated Donut with a fruit filling in it. Only a quarter of the pastry gets filled, at most, the rest of it is just delicious dough. Other than that everything was a hit with me and my family. They deserve their five-star ratings.
Perfect if you want a authentic German bakery (even the limited hours are like being back in Germany so call ahead to make sure they are open)

Beesting cake and pretzel croissants. You're welcome.
Just about everything is phenomenal here, and I'm pretty sure you can't go wrong no matter what you get, but the two items above are my favorites.

Staff is super friendly: if you don't know what to get, they're happy to suggest some items and explain what's in the different pastries. Don't forget to check the discount table for 30% off of day-old bread loaves.

Pricing is super reasonable and quality is astounding. Location is a bit of a drive for me, but I'll go out of my way to come here. Heads up that sometime they forget to turn on their OPEN light, but they are open til 2PM on Sundays.

Was looking forward to the Brochen rolls as we previously enjoyed them from a previous visit. Unfortunately when we got home and removed them from the bag, we were disappointed the rolls were some other type of roll--not the true brochen. They were way too large and not crunchy.
The pretzels were not up to par either.
However, the cherry crumb was tasty.
I'm sure we'll make another trip though sometime in the near future.

This place is absolutely wonderful!
The german cheescake is delicous, I just tried the almond pastry and about died on the spot from happiness.  Ive tried about 6 different things and have not been disapointed.
The lady who is always there is so sweet and pleasant.
Wish it was closer to me. :)

Alright! I wish I would have checked in here when we were visiting family members in Las Vegas, but I forgot to. Anyways, let me tell you what.... if you are in the area, and want to try something truly amazing, beyond amazing, go here and get a piece of their Bee Sting cake. I am not kidding you this is amazing stuff! We tried a lot of their items. We got a big box to go, and we did get doubles of a lot of things, but then I asked the lady who worked there what their most popular item was and she pointed to the Bee Sting cake, which didn't catch my eye at first. I told her to put one slice in the box. My boyfriend and I started eating all of the things on the way home (to California) and then we got to the final piece of Bee Sting cake. Let me tell you that once I tasted it, I was half tempted to make him turn around and drive back into Las Vegas to get me more of it. I did NOT want to share it with him! I started to whine. I told him it was the absolute BEST thing I have ever eaten! I whined about it because it was absolutely delicious, and I shoved it in my mouth and made a huge mess all over my face. I did have to share with him, because once he tasted it, he was whining for more. Damn! Cake never tasted so good! 

I love your Bee Sting cake! And, I will always stop here when I come to Vegas, just so I can order a lot of pieces of it! Yum!

The pretzel croissants are to die for. Everything I have had here has been amazing, actually... But we go back almost every Saturday just for the pretzel croissants. And... Everyone who works there is super nice and so patient while I stand there undecided drooling over all their yummy offerings! :)

Planned a German-style Easter brunch and this is the *only* place hubby would go to for brotchen rolls and country bread. He insists it's just like the baked goods he enjoyed in Germany.  Brotchen are hard crust rolls, with a delectably lighter bread interior, and they are a great match for soft-boiled eggs, artisan cheeses and meats, and fruit preserves. The farmer style country bread works well, too, for sandwiches and toast. (For convenience and consistency, ask them to slice it for you unless you have a bread slicer at home.)

Concerned their stock would run low if we waited until too late in the day, which does happen, we stalked the premises on the Saturday before Easter until the "open" light was turned on.  Hilarious. However, everyone enjoyed having the authentic brotchen on Easter morning so it was well worth getting up early to be at the German Bread Bakery by 7am.
AMAZING German breads!!  Their pretzels are fabulous!  Soft and fresh!!  Don't miss out this place!!
I was so happy when I came across this bakery! My family is German and they had so many familiar goodies. I ordered pastries and breads and they were all delicious. Very nice service too:)
Best pretzels and pastries in Las Vegas! I love the vibe and the women that work there are awesome!

Awesome. We have finally found a place that makes authentic brochen (german rolls). Unfortunately it's ~1200 miles away from home! Still that's quite a lot closer than traveling to Deutschland proper...

The rolls were just right, and per my fiancee we've finally found a German bakery that 'gets it right'. She's been looking for a place that makes the stuff she remembers from living in Germany years ago, so I trust her expertise on that. 

We got 2 of the brochen, a strawberry danish and strawberry crumb cake for $5 even. It was very, very good and filled us up quite nicely. It was actually the best (also the cheapest!) breakfast I've had in the vegas area for some time!

A tip for fellow vegas-area tourists who might be driving there using a GPS gadget as we did: our GPS got a little confused based on the street address and identified a spot along Rampart Blvd where there obviously was no store. The bakery is located at the large intersection near the street address location, in the strip mall near the supermarket. It's easy to miss from the road but with some exploration you'll be able to find it quickly. 

Also to address a point made in other reviews, it's true they don't have any seating inside the store (there might have been a small table and 2 chairs, if that). However immediately outside there are stone benches at the strip-mall. Yes, it's parking-lot ambiance which typically isn't the best place to have a little picnic, but the food was so great that we couldn't have cared less. You might not want to eat this stuff in a renal car unless you want to risk an extra cleaning charge. 

We'll definitely be back. It's off the beaten path for a tourist, but definitely worth seeking out.
Authentic German breads and pastries. Fresh wursts and butter in the cold case. Tasty little extras to buy. Reminds me of my grandmother every time I walk in :)

Nice find.  This is not a standard cake bakery, but a great satellite German bakery.  Their products are all made in their own Central bakery (according to the employee I interacted with). The sweet items are high quality and fairly priced.  They also often have a 1/2 price/day-old shelf.  The winners are the Bee Sting Cake, and the Cherry CrumbCake.  The cherry filling is spiced old world style and not so sweet. The almost twist is also a winner; with a good amount of marzipan. They close early and run out is items early afternoon.

Best bakery around, the pretzels are to die for, especially pretzel croissants,  must order these, and don't just get one, they're awesome you'll be upset with yourself.  Pastries are very good and large. I come for homemade rye bread, so fresh and the pretzels.  Must try, you won't be here just once after your first visit.

German cheesecake is one of absolute favorite and this place nailed it! And the Apple pie pastry is to die for!! All the pastries I purchased were phenomenal and I highly recommend it to anyone who loves authentic German pastries.

The Skinny: can't get past the poor textures of custards and puddings in their pastries (2) it's a bakery so there really isn't a place to sit and they only do credit card transactions over $5 (3) value: given that there pastries were not that great, I'd say this place rates a (2).

I'm a carboholic so when I read about German Bread Bakery, I knew we had to hit it. My hubby and I happened to be in the neighbourhood  right when the bakery opened so we decided we'd to get a couple pastries to go.

Back in my hometown, we have a little German bakery as well which served a great beesting cake; a layer cake filled with pastry cream and topped with honey and almonds. Seeing they had this concoction available too, we decided to give this one a try. Also we saw people post multiple pictures of the pudding danish, so we decided to pick one of those up too.

The beesting cake was pretty disappointing. Although the almond topping and cake was okay, the pastry cream had a very unpleasant powdery texture that really turned me off considering that it composed of 50% of the concoction. It was like eating a teaspoon of cornstarch. Not good. Not good at all.

Next came the pudding danish. My hubby was checking out the danish and poked the pudding part with his fork. I kid you not, the fork bounced back and left not a mark on surface of the pudding. 

"Look, baby! The pudding has memory!"

Yeah, it was that bad. Having the consistency of a rubber band, there was way too much gelatin or agar to solidify their pudding. The danish itself was okay - a little on the doughier side of things than what I'd prefer. It didn't have the flakiness of a fantastic puff pastry.

Given the disappointing experience with both the pudding pastry and the beesting cake, it gets a 2 star.

ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS! This is a gem! We came on a weekday afternoon, so they had sold out of some of their pastries -- come early if you want the best selection! The woman working there was incredibly helpful in explaining what everything was as well as making recommendations. They sell several pretzel-inspired items and we ended up going with the pretzel roll, the crunch stick, and the pretzel croissant. All of these were very good. The pretzel roll was light and fluffy on the inside, but had the right amount of pretzel crisp on the outside. I would have loved to eat this with some cheese or mustard. The pretzel croissant was a denser croissant with pretzel toppings. My favorite was the crunch stick! The phylo dough was perfectly flaky and crispy. We also got the day-old cheese cake--sold at a reduced price--to try it out. German cheesecake is slightly different from "American" cheese cake. Their cheesecake didn't have the graham cracker crust and was less sweet, which I actually prefer. Definitely worth the visit and I hope to visit it again!

Went here on a whim (July 5, 2011) after dropping off some shoes to be repaired a few doors down.  I am a baked goods fiend and had heard of this bakery but kept forgetting to visit.  I'm glad I did!  The selection wasn't huge, as the holiday was the previous day, but what they did have looked fresh and homey.  I bought a loaf of the 3-seed bread and it proved to be fresh and not full of sugar and other crap.  The nice lady behind the counter said that they don't like to use a lot of sugar and that they like to keep things healthy (at least for their bread...).  Value seemed pretty good as my very heavy loaf was ~$5.50.  The bread is still fresh the day after purchase.  I will come here again and often for the bread and to sample some pastries.

Friendly, helpful service, and I'm not just saying that because the woman behind the counter pronounced my name correctly. (Although I'm a bit of a sucker for that.) With a nod to these linguistic skills, I was certainly charmed/dazzled to listen to the conversation she had in German with the customers before us. Yep, GBB is the real deal.

We purchased four pretzels, two crusty sticks, a loaf of dark rye (thinly sliced on request), a loaf of white (not sliced because it's very soft), a cheese danish, a raisin roll, and one piece of the seasonal chocolate-covered gingerbread. All of this came to around $25, plus the free advice to not refrigerate the bread. It can be frozen; otherwise it will last about five days on the countertop.

The cheese danish was lovely - succulent, even. One of those rich pieces where halfway through you're full, but it's so good, how can you stop eating?

The gingerbread seemed a little pricey at $2 for a small rectangle, but when I tried a small bite and the full flavours and aroma hit me, I only regretted that we didn't get a second one so I wouldn't have to share.

Pretzels were the definition of what a good pretzel should be, and until I had these I didn't know that all previous pretzels had fallen short of the mark. Salty, crusty, and chewy, but still so light!

The rye I've only tried a nibble of before realizing that I wasn't really in the mood for a rye that didn't have caraway seeds and a light crumb. So, that's my fault for wanting one thing but ordering something else. That said, the bit I tried seemed to have a good, hearty-yet-not-a-brick taste without being overbearing. I'll look forward to grilling it into sandwiches with a little havarti and sauerkraut later.

(The other items were my husband's to try - I'll let him write his own review.)

I was happy to overhear that a new location in Henderson will be opening next year. Hopefully it will be a little closer to me than this store at Rampart and Lake Mead - never again will I grab a Wetzel Pretzel or (gasp of shame) nuke up a SuperPretzel and call it acceptable.

Germans take everything seriously, including their pastries. I consider myself lucky to have a German opa (grandfather), just as Las Vegas is very fortunate to have this super authentic German bakery.

Both times I've visited, it has been a challenge to narrow down my selections from the display case and counters of various Bavarian delights. Strudels are formed in an adorable bell shape with fillings of apple or spiced cherries. I was intrigued by the beesting cake, a layer of cake topped with Bavarian cream and crunchy sliced almonds in a honey caramel-- one fine German dessert! I can never pass on a slice of apple crumb cake. They also come up with some special items, such as a chocolate pear cake that I tried recently. It was like a coffee cake containing dark chocolate chips and drizzled with white chocolate.

It's not all about the sweets, as the breads baked here are also amazing. Fresh pretzels are available in various shapes. On my last trip, I picked up a loaf of marble rye that became an instant favorite. This bread has enough flavor to stand on its own, but it also makes for the best sandwiches ever with just a few simple added ingredients. GBB has recently added a section of German groceries, including sauce mixes, some cheeses, chocolates and candies, and other fun food items. There's a curry ketchup that looks very interesting; one of the ladies told me that it is the perfect bratwurst condiment. I can't wait to explore some of these unique options.

Which reminds me, it's time to get back to the German Bread Bakery for another loaf of marble rye, and to see if I'm lucky enough to find any seasonal stollen still on the shelves!

Not impressed.

Purposely drove across town to try some pastries. I know it's late in the day and they wouldn't have much options (it was about 4pm). Got there and they lady was putting everything away saying they closed an hour early during summer... Which the hours didn't reflect on Yelp or even on the hours listed on the door. But she was nice enough to take my order.

Got the pretzel croissant, cherry cobbler thing, chocolate coin, and I asked for a crunch cake and German cheese cake and didn't get the cheese cake and ended up with 2 crunch cakes. Fairly inexpensive for everything though... Less than $14

But nothing was spectacular. I was really looking forward to the pretzel croissant but it was underwhelming. Not that flaky, not buttery, not' pretzely'. The chocolate ring was okay but there's an amazing little bakery in Arizona that is soooooo much better. The cakes were not great. I had a couple bites of each and tossed em. Flavor, texture, presentation, all very average. 

It's not a bad place, but not really something I'd go out of my way for.

My Swiss-German husband saw this place on our way into Smith's and we have to stop in. The selection was a little bit small when we got there, but the pretzel bread was so delicious and authentic. We also got a package of Nuremberg sausages that were excellent! Would recommend!

We happened to drive by this place and thought we'd stop in to see what they had. We ended up getting the German cheese cake and the beesting cake and they were both delicious. Beesting was the better of the two. We also got a loaf of the sunflower rye bread, but we weren't a huge fan. Prices were ok. They have daily specials that are constantly changing.

Came for the pretzel bread and left with a new local favorite. I had a craving for fresh pretzel bread and came across this place online. It's one of the things I love most about Las Vegas, hidden foodie spots in the places you'd least expect. I came in in the morning where there was an awesome selection of pastries and breads. Prices were very reasonable and I found my pretzel bread and chocolate croissant warm and fresh. I'll definitely come back and would absolutely recommend.

I LOVE this place. Just be mindful that for serious quality assurance and freshness they may not always have what you came in for....but that can afford you the chance at something new. Pretzels - in all their forms and Pigs Ears....remember those. But you want to save room for the Almond Coffee Cake or the Pudding Crumb Cake. But seriuosly, the strudel will have you back every time.

Love the pretzel rolls!  Also tried the cheesecake, black forest cake, and a cake with peaches on top.  Everything we had was good.  I was hoping to get some Danish but they were all gone.  The lady that helped me was very friendly.  Will definitely be back to try more goodies.

There really isn't not much you can write about a small German bakery considering all they offer is German pastries and pretzels. Me and Ellen F. came here after a hearty breakfast next door and decided we weren't finished stuffing ourselves yet. 

We've been here several times and we always get pretzels and pretzels rolls, they are to die for! These are some of the most authentic German pretzels I've had since I've been to Munich. They are cooked just right and have just enough salt on them that isn't too much. 

Along with the pretzels I also get a Berliner which is equally awesome. Good amount of powdered sugar and not stingy on the filling, these are puffy so to me you get more bang for the buck so to say. 

The lady that helped us is always friendly and courteous. She was extremely patient while I picked which Berliner I wanted from their glass display and rang us up promptly. If you like German pastries or snacks this is the spot to go to, there aren't to many in town.

So As i was working out in my bootcamp class,  my boyfriend went and got me a delicious pastry from this humble place. He got me the apple danish or pie looking thing. The bread actually tasted like how a good crossant would taste right out of an oven, soft chewy, buttery, and breddy,... not hard and too flakey like most danish and crossants. The apple inside tasted fresh and real and not gobbled up in apple sugar syrup. I tried to keep half of the danish for later since it was pretty large, but it was so yummy.. not too sweet.. just perfect... that i ate it all. Can't wait to go back there so I can pick different ones and try it also!@#$

I love local businesses, especially bakeries and this shop is a gem.  The ladies that work here are so very nice and helpful.  First trip I had to purchase the obligatory apple strudel, but what did I find next to up but cherry strudel.  Both are so tasty, great quality and authentic.  Another time I visited the nice lady mentioned the bee sting cake, and I was stung by this tasty treat.  So nice and would go well with a nice coffee or tea.  The last benefit it is very close to my home and a nice place to go a fun treat!  Their bakery items are delicious as well.  The dark  rolls (unsure if they were pumpernickel or some other grain), but so tasty.  They also have many German products (non-bakery) available which I saw many people came in and purchase.  Check it out it is worth the trip!

Legitimately can call itself a bakery since they have bread and pasteries. I only had the pastries so can't review the breads yet.   The pasteries well made.  The fruit was fresh and texture was good. Had the apple crumb, apple strudle ad a small hazelnut filled cookie.  All delicious.  The pastry on the strudle could have been a little flakier, but i've only had the American versions, can't say if it's authentic or not.  The prices are right also.  I don't think anything was above $3.  I'll return for bread and some pretzels.

What a fantastic find here in Vegas! I am an AF brat and was born in Germany. My native mother still lives there. We found this bakery from a friend who raved about the place. I was a bit skeptical the first time because I was raised on authentic German baked goods. I have to say that this bakery is completely authentic. The Beesting cake is just as I remember it and the crumb cakes are wonderful. We treat ourselves and go to the bakery early Saturday mornings for the Brotchens. I dont like to buy any other bread except for the bread from GBB.  Like others have said, be sure to go early for the best selection. The prices are very reasonable and the staff is always friendly and courteous and there is never a feeling of being rushed even with the lobby full of customers. I love that they have added German grocery items and always stock up on staples that I cant get anywhere else in Vegas. Definitely give this place a visit. You won't be disappointed

As a German I missed good bread here in the States. When I moved to Las Vegas I was pleasantly surprised to learn that they had a real German bakery in town. 

The bread is authentic and tasty, they offer German rolls (white, dark, and pretzel) as well as a wide variety of pastries. 

They have a cooler that includes goodies like real Leberwurst, Teewurst, and Mettwurst. They also offer great German mustard in various flavored to good prices. 

In their shelves they often keep things like Kn√∂del, German salad dressing, jams, and other goodies you only get in Germany. 

The staff is always friendly and helpful. They speak both German and English and are very welcoming. Service is quick and good and prices are reasonable. 

This bakery makes my stay in Vegas so much better!

Everything in this Bakery is absolutely delicious the Apple Danish is probably my favorite oh and the strudel that could be my favorite. Oh and the bread that's my favorite too everything in there is my favorite it's delicious and authentic German very affordable super cheap prices

I usually find baked goods from non-Asian bakeries to be overly sweet.  Sadly, this was the case at German Bread Bakery.  I ordered the pudding danish and apple crumb cake based on yelp recommendations.  The pudding on the pudding danish had a texture similar to firm jello and the crumb was a bit dry.   I liked the apple crumb cake but there was a little too much sugar in the streusel topping for my taste.  I'll have to swing by earlier than 10:30AM next time for a better selection and to sample fresher goods.

The cinnamon rolls here are beautiful but a little disappointing.   Simply put, they look much better than they taste.  I want to be clear, they're not bad.  You wouldn't guess by looking at them, but they're just meh.

I also tried the Poppyseed Coffeecake. Again, a disconnect between appearance and taste.    Never had this before and it's just not for me.  Couldn't eat a bite of it.  Es tut mir Leid.   

OK, so I didn't much care for the pastries.  I'm sure plenty of people do.  Display case was pretty empty when I visited in the early afternoon.  

I will definitely be back to try the bread.  It looks great.

Mikey C says: bis spater, GBB

I came here because it was close to where I work and those who know me know that I love ethnic food establishments. This is a cute authentic bakery! If you have ever been to Germany, they have some delicious pastries! I had this pastry that was similar to a donut, it was delicious! I wish that I took a picture of it. One thing I would like to see is more savory food options.  I know that this is strictly a bakery, but I would like to see them add some lunchtime meal options, especially since they sell frozen German meat and other products in their freezer :)

We have so few german (or european generally) pastrie places in Los Angeles, so I always stop here when I am in town.  Its a family run business, and a great place for apple strudel.  The German cheese cake is ok, its denser than a new york cheesecake, but more cakey, like a dense japanese cheese cake.  I would just skip it, and go with the strudel, or a black forest cake, or something with bavarian cream.  If you aren't feeling so sweet, you could get the pretzel roll.  They also have german coffee here, a bit strong, pairs well with the strudel. get the strudel.

Stopped by and picked up a box of treats to bring to a friend in California. 

Probably the best German pretzels I've had. I've had them in Germany over and over again, and it's normally almost like self-abuse... you just keep getting them again and again even though you don't think they taste that great. Here, au contraire! They are lightly toothsome with a nice, delicate chew to them.

Friends loved the donuts, strudel, and other goodies.
While you'll definitely pay for each item here, they also have day-old breads on sale if you want to check it out but are on a budget. 

For fans of rustic European pastry, you're sure to find something you'll enjoy.

We went to a friend last month and they had gotten several varieties of pastries for dessert, all of which were very good.  When they visited us my husband also went there and got a selection which included Black Forest Roll, Pudding Crumb and a couple of Cinnamon Sticks.  My favorite is the Pudding Crumb.  The sizes of the pasties are large enough to cut them in half or even quarters so everyone can taste a little of each.  Pretzels are also great.

This place is so freaking good.

I've only tried it once. We tried to go a second time, but it's closed on Sundays, much to our chagrin. My boyfriend looked like he needed to take anti-depressants after we found that out (he's from out of town lol). 

The lady working the cash register was very friendly and knowledgable about every pastry I asked her about (which was a lot). She was also very honest; I told her I hate things excessively sweet. She assured me that their items were not that disgusting "American" sweet, which is exactly what I was referring to. She was also not afraid to point out which ones were, to assure that I would be satisfied with all the items we got.

We bought 2 types of pretzel bread and they were the most delicious forms of bread I've ever had. I already liked pretzel bread to begin with, but this was by far the best pretzel bread in all my life (not exaggerating). So fresh and so good omg. We also had this yogurt cake that was so delicious, and an almond bar thing that was more on the forgettable side.

All in all, so amazing. Beautiful tasty products accompanied with great service. Can't wait to try more items!
Pretzels were wonderful and delish. Check the dates on any products on the shelf.

The bread is fantastic, lots of varieties to choose from.  The buns are also very good.  I too found the Pretzels a little doughy but perhaps that's the traditional German recipe....  Nice selection of pastries - of which I've tried the turnovers and the danish - both delish!  I just wish the staff were a little friendlier....not too many smiling faces ...quite stern as a matter of fact...  Some nice German music and decorations could lighten up the mood perhaps?

Small German bread shop that carries breads, pastries, and other German foods.

The store front was clean and organized and all the pastries appeared fresh. The woman working gave us a few extra donuts knowing it was our first time. 

I ordered:

Pretzel roll- chewy on the outside and doughy on the inside

Berliner- not overly sweet like most jelly donuts found in American donut shops. Strawberry jelly is made in house but their is only a small dollop towards the end of the donut 

3 seed bread- all breads are made without sugar and personally I like my bread to be a bit sweet. Bread is chewy, soft in the middle and you can taste how few ingredients are used 

Prices are more than reasonable, customer service is great , and you can taste the freshness in each and every item.

Authentic is all I want in German bakery. I don't care if the person behind the counter is a 330 pound hausfrau with a bushy, barrel mustache with a Jazz Hans tattoo or a healthy Brunhilde Valkyrie with muscular thighs, long blonde braids, and a bosom full of beers. Authenticity. That's it. And, well, for the most part, this place has it.

Elephant ears. That's what they're called elsewhere and I forget the German name, but you get the picture. Palmiers by any other name. These are my absolute favorite item. No, wait, Bienenstich ("bee stings"), THAT is my all-time favorite. Wait, let me take that back... Ich bin ein Berliner. I'm a believer in Berliner. JFK confuscation aside.

What I don't like is the new set-up. (This is a theme with me). Serve good food and stop trying to make me sit. I'm a-dashin' and a-runnin', I'm not a-sittin'. Don't try to make me sit. And don't make me take a stollen upside your head. Just don't (just doug'nt, get it?).

Mine Gootness! Delicious! Very high quality Artisan baked goods. I'm not even a fan of German food but this place change my mind. all the creme cakes are amazing and totally totally worth the price. Don't waste your time getting your bake deliciousness anywhere else. Come here! The Cherry crumb cake is amazing!

Since moving to Las Vegas in June my husband and I have made the most interesting and serendipitous discoveries!! We were driving from the Ace Hardware on Cheyenne toward the Dog Supply Outlet on Sahara today and a teenager was spinning a sign at the northwest corner of Rampart and Lake Mead near the Smith's. The sign said German Bakery with an arrow. I got the young man's attention and he confirmed it was in this shopping center.
We did a safe but rapid turn around to get back to the bakery. (as safe as a Bulgarian-German who was up late last night and did not have lunch can do at 1pm...)
We found the bakery and it had some of his mother's family's traditional berliner pastries, cherry cake, crispy sandwich rolls, cinnamon and raisin rolls, chocolate and almond corner bars, and almond marzipan pastries. My husband's eyes were glazed over and he started relating all the familiar items to the very sweet woman at the counter. She is warm and welcoming and very helpful. I love it when a storekeeper truly appreciates the visitors who chose to come to her shop. There was an older woman there whose mother in law had made the same German delicacies and she too was very excited to have her first visit to the bakery.
We slithered out to the car with our treasures and gobbled down one of the almond marzipan pastries plus a cinnamon roll. Oh how fresh they are! This is truly a great find.
Well now I have no worries where my husband goes when I am working from home because he is either at the dog park or at the German Bread Bakery.  We cannot wait for the Christmas goodies either!!

This Bakery is excellent! I went once for soft pretzels and got some croissants because they looked delicious. I saw they had Appel Strudel so I tried one as well. Everything was wonderful and the woman who helped me was very nice. I went back again a few days later, on Sunday, and they were quite busy but, never the less, I was greeted when I came in and they were happy to help. I got some more desserts to try this time. O.....M.....G.....I wasn't expecting this simple looking "Nougat Ring" to be so delicious .The flavor and different textures make for an addicting dessert . I will certainly be going back for more of those. I tried the Rum Balls because I heard a lot of good about them, for good reason. They ARE delic! I also tried the Cheesecake, yeah, perfect German cheesecake. Loved it all! I'll be ordering from here for any occasion where high quality sweets are necessary (birthdays, holidays, office events, "thank you" gifts, etc). SO much better than your average cupcakes and cookies. I was helped by two different people this Sunday and both were friendly and warm. I will be trying their bread loaves next. Keep it up German Bakery!

Just like grandma used to make.

What a treat to have them in Summerlin!

Very good prices and the display looks great.  Friendly staff and a options outside the typical bakery with German sausages for sale as well.  I tried some pretzels thinking that would be the best option from a German bakery, but it wasn't mind-blowing as expected.  Not much salt, which I like, but the crust wasn't the best.  The inside bread was great, however.  But it comes down to the shell of the pretzel just as much and I wasn't feeling it.  I came in the afternoon so maybe it wasn't as fresh, so I'll give it another try for sure as the prices are outstanding for fresh baked goods.

I've been looking for a great bakery for sometime now, while searching the Las Vegas area for German food we stumbled across this bakery in Summerlin. High quality baked goods. We sampled a few items with their freshly brewed German coffee then purchased a box of cakes and strudel and a bag full of pretzels and specialty breads and rolls. All of which were amazing. Treat yourself to something special and stop in the first chance you get. I would give them ten stars.

Having lived in Germany for 4 years i can tell you this place is as good as it gets. It has all the classic pastries and delicious bread for all your desires. They also conveniently have german coffee for $1.25 perfect for a afternoon snack with your kuchen.
I've been to Germany and I absolutely love their food, bakery, just Germany everything is wonderful. This bakery I have only tried the Beesting and absolutely thought it was authentic and delicious.

An excellent, small German bakery.

First, the pastries are authentic, delicious and inexpensive. The taste brought back memories, the flavor was simple outstanding - typical German pastry, not too much sugar, just right - and the price, well, that surprised me, literally cheaper than any comparable bakery I have been to in the past decade.

Second, served by a German speaking staff that is very pleasant.

Third, well, my compliments to the baker(s). Can't ignore quality food or the one's that create it.

Thus far, I have experienced 6 different items - all very good. 

And last, not so much criticism, as it is preference and suggestions. Increase the prices as necessary so as to add a small sitting area with coffee made available and the required bathroom. The pastries are so good - I want to stay there and eat there, but at the moment, that is not possible. I believe the clients will accept a moderate price increase in exchange for coffees and a nice sitting area, both inside and out. And of course, Wi-Fi, so some could stay longer and enjoy the food and experience.

However, should it not do these suggested items - that's fine. Simply take the pastries and go across the street to Starbucks where everything goes good with a simple coffee.

Perhaps, even a German TV/cable station or some background music may add to the experience.

There are several added German food products that are also available on a few racks at normal prices as best I can tell.

This is a must visit Bakery. Located in the Smiths shopping center on Lake Mead and Rampart, The German Bakery is addicting. 

The hubby is from Germany so when I found out about this little hidden gem i knew I had to surprise him with a treat. I ordered a Cherry Strudel, German Cheesecake, Nugat, and pretzel. Me being allergic to gluten unfortunately I was not able to try anything but he ate everything in 1 day. If i would have bought more he would have eaten that too haha.

He said everything was very traditional in German baking. Not too sweet like a lot of American bakeries. He even went back the next day... Ive created a monster!

Nothing says "Fr√∂hliche Weihnachten!" (Merry Christmas!) like Stollen. I've searched high and low for delicious Stollen in Las Vegas, and all I could find were boxed Stollen that just didn't appeal to me. Ah, but I've finally found the perfect Stollen. Funny, though, it never dawned on me before to visit the German Bread Bakery (duh!). If you've never had a slice or engulfed a whole loaf, then you're in for a treat. Stollen is like fruitcake....

Wait, hold on, don't stop reading! Well, maybe you should because that means there'll be more Stollen for me! But really now....

Stollen can be likened to fruitcake, but its texture is more like bread than cake. Unlike fruitcakes which typically have candied fruits, Stollen doesn't have any of that. The German Bread Bakery's Stollen loaf contains raisins, slivered almonds, marzipan, and is dusted with a nice coat of powdered sugar. A loaf costs $9.95, and I'm guessing it weighed nearly a pound -- indulge, carb lovers.

There's nothing wrong with boxed Stollen (or fruitcake). If you feel inclined to try one, I'd suggest trying Oebel brand that can be found at Cost Plus. However, I don't think I can go back to eating boxed Stollen after having tried German Bread Bakery's. 

Vielen Dank to German Bread Bakery for the awesome Stollen. I think it's about time I give em a 5-Star rating.

What a little gem of a find this bakery is! I was in the parking lot headed to Subway when I noticed it. I thought I would stop in and see what they had for bread. I was surprised at the appetizing variety of goodies they had!
I got a "Apple Danish" and a "Bear Claw" to enjoy for dessert :)
They were so tasty! I wish I noticed this place before but now I can at least stop in and get a danish after eating my healthy Subway right?! *wink wink*

The store was clean and the staff was very friendly and helpful.

As a German bakery, this locally owned shop is unique in a city filled with French and Asian bakeries. The pretzel breads and pastries are the must-try items, particularly the pretzel croissant, that combines the chewiness of a pretzel with the airiness of a croissant. The apple danish is buttery, light and filled with caramelized apples inside with icing dashed across the top. Another apple pastry -- their apple pie -- wasn't as good. With a thin pastry crust on the bottom and top, the middle was full of apples and raisins (which I'm personally not a fan of). It's a far cry from an American version of apple pie, one that I wouldn't get again. Still, they have plenty of other great items to eat.

Traditional German Konditerei with wonderfully dense, moist, so full of flavor breads that aren't heavy. So wonderful to be able to bring Dad am Apfel, Kirshe, or Plum Kuchen, the bee sting cake is heavenly, and you can even get a tasse Koffee to go! A must if you love a wonderful traditional German Bakery like the ones I knew growing up and items like my Oma used to make!
Love this bakery. Amazing breads and goodies. Plus they have actual products from Germany!!! I will definitely go back.

My beau lives 1 minute away and I've always wanted to try this place out. With summer hours, I could never seem to go when they were open since they close early, but we finally caught them the last 10 minutes before they closed today (Sunday).
We ordered:

-Apple Danish 
- jelly donut
- cinnamon donut
- almond horn
- pretzel
- pretzel croissant
- cinnamon roll

These were all so delicious!!! The dough was nice and flaky, not to mention buttery. The pretzel was authentic, chewy,and not too salty. Donuts were pillowy soft. Every single item we got was delicious! I recommend you go on the weekends and early, as they easily run out plus you get the breads freshly out the oven. Since we were the last customers before closing, some of the Danishes were kinda hard, but still tasted fresh not stale. The huge perks of being the last customers was buy one get one free and an additional discount!!! The lady at the counter was super sweet and friendly as well. I recommend this little bakery to everyone in the area, as you will not be disappointed!!!!

ETHNIC BAKERY TOUR #1-GERMANY

We've always driven by this strip mall but never noticed this bakery tucked back in the corner. Not only is this a bakery, but a mini German specialities store as well where a lot of German transplants pick up candies, condiments,and other items for a taste of home.(Curry Ketchup!?!?! COOL!!!) The smell of freshly baked goods immediately draw you in and awaken your tastebuds...(Enter at your own risk!)

Bakery selections are plentiful from different danish, crumb cakes, pretzel breads, almond horns, cheese sticks, and a wide array of whole loaves that they will be happy to slice for you. I was jonezing for some of their Bienenstich, or Beesting Cake which is a yeast dough filled with luscious vanilla custard with a caramelized almond-honey topping, but unfortunately they didn't have any on our visit..:( We settled for a Cherry Danish, a Nut Corner, a Pretzel Bread, a German Cheesecake and a popular item called Frankfurter. The ladies behind the counter are so nice and helpful, they also convinced us to come away with a few goodies!

I am determined to return for that Beesting Cake!.....ALOHA!!!

The customer service is great. The assortment is also very good. I will be a repeat customer,
I'm glad I found this location.

I was on the hunt for Pretzel Buns last January when I came across the German Bread Bakery. The woman at the counter was an absolute doll. Their selection prompted my curiosity. I am a Cheese Danish lover so I snagged one and began nibbling it in the parking lot... AMAZING! My husband fancies their Cherry Strudel. At my last visit I grabbed a loaf of their German Sweet Yeast Bread..... OH MY YUMMY GOODNESS!! I have been in each week to get a loaf. They are always so fresh! I have been playing with recipes that encompass this beautiful bread. French Toast, Grilled Cheese or just a perfect sized slice of toast. Today we purchased a slice German Cheese Cake and the Crumble Pudding Cake..... SO GOOD!

The reason we visited this bakery is because of the reviews on Yelp. OMG!  We tried all three types of pretzel, apple strudel, almond horn, chocolate croissant and more. It was all delicious. So much so, that we plan on going there tomorrow morning to sample some other of their wide variety of yummy goodness. The ladies working there were delightful, genuine and their hearts are deeply vested in the business. It's authentic and worth a trip to experience true homemade baking from the heart of Germany.

Wanted to try this bakery as I read so many great reviews! I purchased shortbread cookies which were very buttery, had a nice texture, and delicious but not too sweet. I also got the Windmill which I recommend. It looked like a windmill with a custard-like cream on top. The cream was rich and creamy but not too sweet. The bkaed part was flaky like a croissant and had glaze on it which added nice sweetness. Definitely recomend!

I called from Henderson to put the cherry crumbs on hold. She said she'd wait a little bit for me after closing! So nice! 

I got cherry crumb and apple crumb. The apple was surprisingly delicious. I don't really like apple. It was even better the day after. Soft, flavorful, and the crumb topping was just divine. It is buttery and sweet and fresh.

From the moment you walk in your greeted by a staff of friendly ladies that are sweet and helpful. At first glance I suddenly felt like I was transported back in Germany 3 years ago when I went to Europe and all the different bakeries they had back in Germany which was very similar in presentation and what they offered here. I purchased 7 items including pretzel roll & stick, German Cheesecake, Apple Strudel, Apple Crumb Cake and Lemon Roll. Everything my family and I had was delicious and fresh. The pretzel bread were amazing, great with cheese or butter. They were soft in the inside and the crispy texture on the outside was consistent. The Apple Strudel and Cheese Cake were filling and dense but sweet enough with every bite. We will back to try so more of their other pasties and bread.
Omg, so great and delicious. True German bread! Thank you so much for having this close to our house.

It's been a while since I have been to this German bakery located in a shopping plaza in Summerlin at which a super-size Smith's store is the anchor tenant. I believe they call this combination of a supermarket and a department store a Smith's Marketplace store.

The fact that the German Bread Bakery, located just around the corner from this Smith's behemoth with a large in-store bakery of it's own, does a brisk business with a loyal clientele of repeat customers throughout the year is an crystal-clear indication of just how delectable virtually everything made and sold in this family-run business must be.

Germans are known for their expertise in making a great variety of breads including diverse rolls, soft pretzels and the like. No matter what type of bread you prefer, you will find something to satisfy your cravings here.

The baked goods - including cakes - made with various fruit fillings/toppings and nuts are invariably first-rate. My personal favorite(s) apart from the apple strudel include all those pastries made with poppy seeds since such items are rarely if ever found at other bakeries around town.

Special orders are welcome, just ask. Especially large orders should be phoned in a few days ahead of your scheduled pickup date to ensure that an adequate supply of German bread and baked goods will also be available for other patrons.

They also have a second store in Las Vegas located on Eastern Avenue to which I have never been since I live here in the wild-and-woolly northwestern part of Sin City.

I stopped in yesterday when I was in this plaza as I had read good things about the bakery on Yelp.   I was disappointed in the rolls I bought.  They were multi-grain topped rye rolls and they were dry.  I haven't yet tried the pretzel rolls.  I hope they're better than the rye ones.

I also bought two cookies, a peanut butter and a chocolate chip.  The peanut butter cookie was good.  The chocolate chip is in the freezer for another day.

Since this isn't my neighborhood, I'll stop elsewhere for baked goods.  I really think the rolls in grocery stores are as good as what I bought yesterday.  The bakery was OK.

I stopped by and wow, what a find.  I wanted to get a simple pastry for the road but ended up buying two almond horseshoes, a pretzel stick, apple strudel, that chocolate thing from belgium, and a loaf of rye bread.  

That almond horseshoe had a unique taste but I liked it.  I wanted another after I was done with the two.  The pretzel stick was good too, I prefer that over the pretzel knot.  I enjoyed the hell out of that rye bread and everything else I bought here.  This isn't the best bakery I've been to but it's damn good and worth stopping by at.  

The staff is friendly and there's a minimum amount you need to purchase in order to use a debit/credit card.

I lived in Germany for 5 years... this place is legit.  I hadn't had a br√∂tchen in 9 years... and it tasted just like I remembered. The other pastries we ordered brought back fond memories of the pastries we would have in Germany. Everything we bought was fantastic!! I can't wait to go back.  

Give this place a try if you want the "real deal" in German pastries and breads.

Genuine German bakery that never fails to serve great food.

I was out one day and needed something a little sweet and dropped in to see what's what.

First thing  when I walked in was an actual German family that works there, And greeted me with a smile. 

Second thing I noticed was the Bee-sting cake!!! This you'll see everywhere in all bakery's in Australia and Germany! I was really surprised to see it, so I purchased the whole cake!!! I know I'm Piggy but when you get something good, get all of it.

They also supply a few European items like sausage, chocolate and other cooking supplies that you might only find in international stores.

For sure one of the great family bakery's in Las Vegas.

Overall 
Service: 5-5
Food: 5-5
Cleanliness: 5-5
Coming back: yes

Though my visit to the German Bread Bakery was brief lasting only about 5 minutes, it was a good 5 minute first impression.  I was struck first by the smell of fresh baked goods.  I love that smell.  It reminds me of growing up when I would bake with my mom and my grandma.  Especially around the holidays.

There was nobody up front when I first walked in but the lady came out almost right away and asked how she could help me.  She was not a Chatty Kathy but not unfriendly either.  Just very professional with her answers in a German accent.  I asked her about a couple of things and told her it was my first time to the shoppe.  She told me about the bee sting cake which I had heard about through Yelp.  I was already leaning towards trying that and she just pushed me a little closer to the decision.  Close enough that it was decided and I ordered one of those.  I also was eyeing the rum balls.  I like rum and I like chocolate so that was a no brainer.  I ordered one of those as well.  Next thing I know I was being rung up ($4 and change) and instructed to keep the bag on its side so that the sweets inside would not get all messed up.

I took these treats home with me and broke into the rum ball first.  It was the smaller of the two and I was kind of full from lunch an hour earlier.  This was the perfect size for a mid day dessert.  The first thing I notice is that it does not appear to be baked at all.  It seems almost like under cooked brownies with some grit.  Not in a bad way at all.  Infact, I loved it 100%.  I looked up some recipes to see exactly what it was.  The best I can figure is chocolate, sugar, butter, ground hazel nuts, and rum.  Perhaps even some toasted coconut.  There aint nothin' wrong with that.  It was so good.  A little sweet.  A little drunk.  Divinely evil.

I tried the bee sting cake later in the day for my after dinner dessert.  I was only going to have a few bites of what was actually a rather big piece of cake.  That plan was quickly tossed aside after the first bite proved too much to ignore.  It was not overly sweet as I expected it to be.  The cake is more of a yeast bread and is a little dry compared to traditional cake.  There are two layers of this baked good with a Bavarian cream in the middle.  On the top is a caramelized almond cap with honey.  That is where the bulk of the sweetness seemed to be but even that was not too sweet.  It was just right.  Before I knew it the entire piece was gone and I found myself wanting more.  I love almonds, honey and Bavarian cream.  This is like a trifecta of goodness.

I will have to go back for some other baked goods.  Like pretzels and rolls.  There are many other desserts to try as well.  It may take me a few more visits to try it all.  Oh darn the luck.

The food is great and I love that they use whole ingredients.  However, I had hoped this would be my local bread store but they nickel and dime you literally.  Doesn't make it feel like a local spot when they want to charge a nickel for an extra bag to regular customers.  The is LITERALLY nickel and diming people and doesn't seem like a good business choice.  Just annoys me.  Also wish they had a place to sit and enjoy the bakery.
Amazing!  The sweet yeast bread and making French toast is becoming a family tradition. Highly recommend.

Love this place. They had bloodwurst and stollen for the holidays. For my boyfriends birthday the made a special bread in the shape of a turtle. So nice, very fresh breads and pastries. Looking forward to the stollen again this year.

Chocolate croissant? Yes please!!! My love for chocolate croissants and the fact that I was right across the street led me to this bakery. Parking is a bit tight in that shopping center but where there's chocolate there's a way. I saw exactly what I wanted right away. I didn't look around but my husband did ask what the black and white cookies are. After paying 3 bucks for my croissant I was on my way home. 

The verdict: the croissant wasn't very flaky and light as I prefer it to be. Instead it was very bready and doughy if that miss sense. It felt like a piece of bread with chocolate inside. It was fairly large but this wasn't the "amazing I want to go back there now type of deal."  Overall, if I'm in the neighborhood I might drop by.

I have been wanting to try this place for sometime after reading the reviews and seeing the pictures.  My mouth was watering just waiting to bite into the famous bee sting cake, well the wait continues as they did not have any. Apparently they get the bee sting cake in on Friday's and it usually sells out by Monday. So we went with the bear claws, cherry and apple crumb cakes and cherry strudel. The bear claws were huge but that was because once you bite into them they are full of air and not much else, never seen a bear claw with no almonds on top. For $2.75 I expected much more. The cherry filling used in the crumb cake and the strudel was unsweetened and rather bland, and they were both so cold when we got them home and ate them that I wonder if they were frozen at one time. I am going to go back when they have the bee sting cake and hope they can redeem themselves and live up to other reviews.

The walnut bread here is ADDICTIVE!! The pastries are so tasty and perfect. Not overly sweet either but just right. Everyone I have met here is very nice and helpful. I think this place is the real deal when it comes to German bread and pastry authenticity. No disappointments here.

Bee-sting cake! Bee-sting cake! Bee-sting cake! Do not leave without ordering AT LEAST one of those things. 
The couple in front of us spoke German and seemed to know what they were ordering so we ended up copying their entire order. 
The cinnamon swirl was 99 cents, but hard and too sugary- not my favorite.  
The almond coffee cake was soft and had a nice almond filling in the center. You might want to skip it if you aren't a nutty, almond lover. 5/5 for me. 
The cheesecake tasted very similar to the almond coffee cake. Do not expect it to taste like American cheesecake. 4/5. 
They normally accept credit cards, but their machine wasn't working when we went in. Make sure you have cash! Their day old bread is significantly discounted- lots of rolls and loaves!

My girlfriend and I (who is German) stopped by here for breakfast yesterday. We were really excited because of the good reviews, and we figured this would be a great place to have around for when she misses home. 

The two woman working were from Germany and were so friendly! We talked with them for a little bit, alternating between German and English, and they even gave us tips about where to find other German items throughout Las Vegas. 

We ended up ordering two of their muffins which were really really good, and two Berliners which even though we ate half a day later (and they had sit in a hot car), they were delicious and fresh. 

We also got two cups of coffee which were great German quality, and we really enjoyed it. 

They also have some German groceries and candy, though the shelves were a little bare while we were there. However they told us a big shipment was coming in next week so they should have a lot more than. They have sauerkraut and haribo candy, and they also have those little Maggi sauce packets with recipes for making a dinner with it. We love those and are happy they're there! They also of course have a variety of wurst for sale. 

The biggest disappointment of this place is that they didn't have chairs and tables to sit down and eat breakfast. We were hoping this was more like a cafe, and that it would be our regular spot to enjoy a nice breakfast our snack in a cafe, but we found ourselves leaving and looking around to find a place to sit down. We ended up in the park down the road, but still. If they add tables and chairs, we would come a lot more frequently!
Raisin bread loaf is dense and moist but their plain bread (same $4.50 price as the raisin bread) is disappointingly dry.  Not returning here.

Hubby and I were in Las Vegas visiting a friend for a few days. I wanted to pick up a quick something before driving back to California so I found this place on Yelp. We had high hopes since there were so many great reviews. We bought 6 different things- pastries and pretzel bread. Sadly the only thing I enjoyed eating was the pretzel bread. The pretzel bread was really good but everything else was really bad. Bear claw was tough something else with almond slices was also tough and bad. Other than the pretzel we took maybe one or 2 bites of each and threw them away. Disappointing really.

I walk into the shop and am pleasantly greeted with the sounds of a lively conversation happening in the German language. The jovial conversation is between the employee and a customer. After they finished their conversation I watched as the customer left with a large bundle of goodies. She was stocking up. I wonder what goodies she selected for her bags.

There are 2 locations of the German Bread Bakery. They are located far across town from each other. 

I come in often for the pretzel products. There is something addicting about the bitterness of the pretzel bread alongside the flaky salt crystals. I adore the thin layer of hard pretzel crust encompassing the soft dense bread inside.
Hard to beat  fresh baked pastry and this Bakery is as good as it gets.  Great breats, rolls and of course pastries and cakes.  Yum Yum Yum!!!

This place is delicious. Their buns are amazeballs... For realz. Get some pretzel buns and make sure you eat them that day, they're not as amazing the next day, but they're still pretty great if you microwave them for about 45seconds. 

Get it. eat it. Love it.

Delicious!  My husband and kids dragged me into it to get some sweet pastries.  Wasn't going to have any, but I tried a little piece and really liked it.  They taste a little bit different but all very good.  Customer service is great.
Really authentic german bakery, everything is great. Sometimes customers and owner conversing back and forth in German.

Delicious pastries especially the poppy-seed roll.  I liked the pretzels which were a bit sour but seemed authentic.  The beesting pastry was also very yummy, just wish there was more Bavarian cream.  The sunflower bread was liked a lot by my bro-in-law, but sis, mom, and I weren't terribly fond.  They should have samples to try the different breads so that we can find one we like.  Overall, appreciate the mom-and-pop aspect to the shop instead of the dreaded chains and the yummy goodies didn't hurt either.

The pretzel croissant doesn't appear that special at first, but it really does combine that distinct lye flavor with a a lighter flakier croissant. Yum.

The BeeSting cake here is more bready than other places. But the honey almond top keeps me eating this one.

The apple strudel has a wonderful duel personality crust. Shortbready on the bottom and flaky on top. Too bad its 'bakers canned apple filling', but unless they double the price of the strudel, this is perfectly understandable.
Love their light rye bread. Wish they had it with caraway seeds also. Bought apple strudel, it was ok, sugar on top was not needed. They also sold Rollmops (pickled Herring) super good.

Love this bakery! You can always satisfy your sweet tooth without breaking your wallet. German pastries are not as sweet as French or American ones so keep that in mind, but that's why I like it. The beesting cake is a favorite of mine. It has honey and slivered almonds. They also have big pretzels. Give this bakery a try!

After getting a Pretzel Croissant across town at CraftHaus Brewery, I had to stop by the bakery responsible for this wonderful treat.

We arrived a little later in the afternoon and that's something I don't like to do in regards to bakeries since you know the best items are gone after morning. There was still a decent selection and though not much, there were still four Pretzel Croissants left!

So, I took home Preztel Croissants ($1.15/ea) and Pretzel Sticks ($0.95/ea). There was also a sliced loaf of Caraway Bread on sale (day old goods) that I was happy to take since I love caraway seeds. Everything is great. We threw the pretzels into the convection oven at 350F for ten minutes and they were perfectly warm, soft, with a little crust. Yum!

AS DISAPPOINTING AS ANY BAKERY PRODUCT I HAVE EVER TASTED

The beesting cake, cheesecake, and Black Forest cakes were the most tasteless, dry desserts I have ever served.  Fortunately my friends were candid and expressed their very negative opinions of the pastries.  We suspect the products were baked at least two days prior to purchase.

In fairness, the apple strudel was "good" but nothing special.

What an expensive waste of money spent at this supposedly "fantastic" bakery.  Nothing could be further from the truth.  Positive reviews of this unattractive business should be considered suspect.

Located in the same shopping area as Smiths on Rampart is the  German Bread Bakery.

I had seen a few reviews on yelp and decided to give them a try on a beautiful Saturday afternoon.

Service was super friendly which was very nice. Baked goods selection seemed a bit slim, nonetheless I managed to find the bee sting cake people had mentioned in their reviews. 

Beesting cake quickly was in the company of a few other things that husband and I had chosen. Not being familiar with German Bread or German pastries in any way whatsoever, I can only compare it to what we know.

The beesting topping was harder than expected, but still delicious and the rest of it was very soft. Apple pastry of some sort was not filled with that much apple filling at all, seemed to be a bit hollow with one tiny, little cube of apple :( . Again, not knowing if this is how it was suppose to be, or did this one simply get missed?! Im guessing it should've had more.  ;)

Overall Im a huge fan of small businesses with great customer service. Based on those two factors alone I would give 5 stars, however with a smaller selection than expected I have to give 4 stars for the time being. I probably will go back and give them another try. Enjoy!!
My mother was from Germany so I grew up with a lot of German food in my life. I'm glad this place is so close. Everything I've tried from here is great!
They offer hard to find fresh breads and bakery items.   Some of my favorites:  stollen, rum balls, pumpernickel, pig ears, almond horseshoes, and rye bread.

I have gone before to the German Bread Bakery and purchased bread which I really like. I mostly purchase the dark rye and can recommend that one.  Having been born and raised in Germany I have to say it comes pretty close to the real thing. Pastries now on the other hand, I am not so happy with. The Bienenstich is good, its probably my favorite but this last time I purchased the Cherry Crumb Cake and I was very disappointed. It appeared like the cherry filling was out of a can, there were only a few cherries and the rest of the filling was like glue. Cherry Crumb Cake should have real cherries and not pie filling in it or thickened juice. So needless to say I was not happy, I have had their Black Forrest Cake, it was okay but not great, the same goes for the Cheese cake. So please if you have never been to Germany do not judge my countries pastries by this place. I have to give them a 'yes I am a fan' for the bread, but for the pastries, with the exception of the Beesting Cake, I have to give them a 'methinks NOT' However, the staff is very friendly and always willing to help, so that is a plus.

I came here after my friend told me about this place , tbh I am not a huge bread person but I love pretzels.. When I arrived Mona was busy helping someone who speaks German and they were going to town.. Once it was my turn she was super friendly introduced herself and helped me pick out all kinds of goodies ... The BeeSting cake was delicious and I love all the pretzel options .. This place is delicious and reasonably priced for the quality and freshness!!!! Plus the service is amazeballs

Finally stopped in here today to check the place out. I love baked goods (who doesn't?!) and this place is amazing. Homemade bread, pastries, rolls, and amazing desserts. I purchased a bear claw, poppy cake, and a loaf of white bread. The white bread was a perfect density, had a crackly crust and so soft inside. Even though it was sliced thin (which I love) it worked perfect for my lunchtime sandwich. There was also a daily special of 10% off pastries, and one day old bread for 30% which can be frozen to preserve! I'm definitely going back often!
Everything is so fresh and a great atmosphere authentic German bakery. Will keep coming back. Found it by chance glad we did. And the food tastes great

Really excellent bakers here.  The bread is fantastic and their desserts are big but, unlike some other places in town, are actually very good as well.  Getting a big, crappy dessert is a bummer but no problems here.
Get there early as a lot of the good stuff will sell out if you wait until after work.

Delicious desserts! I tried the cherry cobbler, German cheese cake and pudding cake. The lady at the front was very nice, The prices are reasonable and it's close to my house. When I want to impress guests but don't feel like baking this is my go to bakery:)

German Bread Bakery:

It is a delight to find such a nice bakery in Summerlin for tasty, authentic German pastries! Thanks to fellow Yelpers for telling me about this place! I've already been there 3 times past 5 days!
- Do try its delicious soft pretzel rolls ($0.75) and apple strudels ($2?), among other treats! The pretzel stick and pretzel twist ($1.40) are actually made from the same dough, but more expensive for being larger in size? Go there during the morning, if you want the pretzel rolls, which are usually the first ones to go!
- Its pumpernickel loaf ($4.99) is tasty, but a bit on the hard and dry side especially after a day; not quite suitable for making a sandwich with.
- The bakery also carries some meat/grocery items, which I have not yet sampled, however.

- This bakery is quite small, but bright and inviting, what with its glass window & glass door, not to mention the wonderful aroma permeating in the air and the nice display of tempting goodies!

There are three nice ladies working there. Two of them are extra friendly and cheerful! They speak German to each other, as well as to some German speaking customers.
